Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as a form of government censorship that undermines the ability of Australians to share and discuss important issues freely.
The bill should be abandoned or repurposed to focus on corporate and government-owned media rather than individual Australians.
Existing government agencies and laws are sufficient to handle misinformation without additional powers for ACMA.
The justification for the bill is considered weak, with no credible evidence of harm that necessitates such legislation.
The COVID-19 response is cited as an example of government and media misinformation causing harm, suggesting ulterior motives for the bill.
Notable Quotes: There is no imperative for the Government to intervene in the ability of the majority of Australians to make informed decisions by censoring information.
Examination of the justifications for this Bill yielded zero imperatives with the flimsiness and lack of anything credible pointing to ulterior as yet undisclosed motives by Government.
The greatest peacetime catastrophe to cause harm to Australians was COVID Intervention imposed through a Government and GOV coordinated media marketing campaign.
